revisions.rev:
{{Infobox programming language | name = R | logo = [[Image:Rlogo.png|200px]] | paradigm = [[Multi-paradigm programming language|multi-paradigm]]: [[Object-oriented programming|object-oriented]], [[Imperative programming|imperative]], [[Functional programming|functional]], [[Procedural programming|procedural]], [[Reflective programming|reflective]] | year = 1993<ref>[http://cran.r-project.org/doc/html/interface98-paper/paper_2.html A Brief History] R: Past and Future History, Ross Ihaka, Statistics Department, The University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand, available from the CRAN website</ref> | designer = [[Ross Ihaka]] and [[Robert Gentleman (statistician)|Robert Gentleman]] | developer = R Development Core Team | latest_release_version = 2.14.0 | latest_release_date = {{start date and age|2011|10|31}} | latest_test_version = Through [[Subversion (software)|Subversion]] | latest_test_date = | typing = [[dynamic typing|Dynamic]] | implementations = | dialects = | influenced_by = [[S (programming language)|S]], [[Scheme (programming language)|Scheme]] | influenced = | operating_system = [[Cross-platform]] | license = [[GNU General Public License]] | website = [http://www.r-project.org www.r-project.org] | wikibooks = R Programming }} '''R''' is a [[programming language]] and software environment for [[statistics|statistical]] computing and graphics. The R language is widely used among statisticians for developing statistical software,<ref>{{ cite journal | author = Fox, John and Andersen, Robert | title = Using the R Statistical Computing Environment to Teach Social Statistics Courses | publisher = Department of Sociology, McMaster University | date = January 2005 | url = http://www.unt.edu/rss/Teaching-with-R.pdf | format = [[PDF]] | accessdate = 2006-08-03 }}</ref><ref name="nytimes09">{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/07/technology/business-computing/07program.html |title=Data Analysts Captivated by R's Power | date=2009-01-06 | accessdate=2009-04-28|last=Vance| first=Ashlee |work=[[New York Times]]| quote=R is also the name of a popular programming language used by a growing number of data analysts inside corporations and academia. It is becoming their lingua franca...}}</ref> and R is widely used for statistical software development and data analysis.<ref name=nytimes09/>
R is an implementation of the [[S (programming language)|S programming language]] combined with [[lexical scoping]] semantics inspired by [[Scheme (programming language)|Scheme]]. S was created by [[John Chambers (programmer)|John Chambers]] while at [[Bell Laboratories|Bell Labs]]. R was created by [[Ross Ihaka]] and [[Robert Gentleman (statistician)|Robert Gentleman]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://myprofile.cos.com/rgentleman | title=Robert Gentleman's home page | accessdate=2009-07-20}}</ref> at the [[University of Auckland]], [[New Zealand]], and now, R is developed by the ''R Development Core Team'', of which Chambers is a member. R is named partly after the first names of the first two R authors (Robert Gentleman and Ross Ihaka), and partly as a play on the name of [[S (programming language)|S]].<ref>{{cite book |title=The R FAQ: Why is R named R? |author=Kurt Hornik |isbn=3-900051-08-9 |url=http://cran.r-project.org/doc/FAQ/R-FAQ.html#Why-is-R-named-R_003f |accessdate=2008-01-29 }}</ref>
R is part of the [[GNU project]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://directory.fsf.org/project/gnur/ | title=Free Software Foundation (FSF) Free Software Directory: GNU R | accessdate=2010-07-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.r-project.org/about.html | title=What is R? | accessdate=2009-04-28}}</ref> Its [[source code]] is freely available under the [[GNU General Public License]], and pre-compiled binary versions are provided for various [[operating system]]s. R uses a [[command line interface]]; however, several [[graphical user interface]]s are available for use with R.
== Statistical features == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:R gui on os x.png|thumb|right|The R [[gui]] running the general linear model demo on Mac OS X.]] --> R provides a wide variety of [[statistical]] and [[graphical]] techniques, including [[linear]] and [[nonlinear]] modeling, classical statistical tests, [[time-series analysis]], classification, clustering, and others. R is easily extensible through functions and extensions, and the R community is noted for its active contributions in terms of packages. There are some important differences, but much code written for S runs unaltered. Many of R's standard functions are written in R itself, which makes it easy for users to follow the algorithmic choices made. For computationally intensive tasks, [[C (programming language)|C]], [[C++]], and [[Fortran]] code can be linked and called at run time. Advanced users can write C or [[Java (programming language)|Java]]<ref>{{cite |title=Calling R from Java |author=Duncan Temple Lang |url=http://www.omegahat.org/RSJava/RFromJava.pdf |accessdate=2010-07-05 }}</ref> code to manipulate R objects directly.
R is highly extensible through the use of user-submitted packages for specific functions or specific areas of study. Due to its S heritage, R has stronger [[object-oriented programming]] facilities than most statistical computing languages. Extending R is also eased by its permissive [[lexical scoping]] rules.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Jackman | first = Simon | title = R For the Political Methodologist | journal = The Political Methodologist | volume = 11 | issue = 1 | pages = 20â22 | date = Spring 2003 | publisher = Political Methodology Section, [[American Political Science Association]] | url = http://polmeth.wustl.edu/tpm/tpm_v11_n2.pdf | format = [[PDF]] | accessdate = 2006-08-03 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060721143309/http://polmeth.wustl.edu/tpm/tpm_v11_n2.pdf |archivedate = 2006-07-21}}</ref>
According to [[Rexer's Annual Data Miner Survey]] in 2010, R has become the [[data mining]] tool used by more data miners (43%) than any other.<ref>http://www.rexeranalytics.com/Data-Miner-Survey-Results-2010.html</ref>
Another strength of R is static graphics, which can produce publication-quality graphs, including mathematical symbols. Dynamic and interactive graphics are available through additional packages such as [[RGL]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://cran.r-project.org/web/views/Graphics.html | title=CRAN Task View: Graphic Displays & Dynamic Graphics & Graphic Devices & Visualization | publisher=The Comprehensive R Archive Network | accessdate=2011-08-01 }}</ref>
R has its own [[LaTeX]]-like documentation format, which is used to supply comprehensive documentation, both on-line in a number of formats and in hard copy.
== Programming features == R is an interpreted language typically used through a [[command line interpreter]]. If one types "2+2" at the command prompt and presses enter, the computer replies with "4".
<source lang = "rsplus"> > 2+2 [1] 4 </source>
Like many other languages, R supports [[Matrix (mathematics)|matrix arithmetic]]. R's [[data structure]]s include [[Scalar (computing)|scalars]], [[Column vector|vectors]], [[Matrix (mathematics)|matrices]], data frames (similar to [[Table (database)|tables]] in a [[relational database]]) and [[List (computing)|lists]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Dalgaard |first=Peter |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Introductory Statistics with R |year=2002 |publisher=Springer-Verlag |location=New York, Berlin, Heidelberg |isbn=0387954759X pages=10â18, 34 }}</ref> The R object system has been extended by package authors to define objects for [[Regression analysis|regression models]], [[time-series]] and [[Spatial analysis|geo-spatial coordinates]].
R supports [[procedural programming]] with [[Function (computer science)|functions]] and, for some functions, [[object-oriented programming]] with [[generic function]]s. A generic function acts differently depending on the type of arguments it is passed. In other words the generic function [[Dynamic dispatch|dispatches]] the function ([[Method (computer science)|method]]) specific to that type of [[Object (computer science)|object]]. For example, R has a [[Generic function|generic]] print() function that can print almost every type of [[Object (computer science)|object]] in R with a simple "print(objectname)" syntax.
Although R is mostly used by statisticians and other practitioners requiring an environment for statistical computation and software development, it can also be used as a [[numerical linear algebra|general matrix calculation]] toolbox with performance benchmarks comparable to [[GNU Octave]] or [[MATLAB]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sciviews.org/benchmark | publisher=SciView | title=Speed comparison of various number crunching packages (version 2) | accessdate=2007-11-03 }} </ref>
== Examples == === Example 1 === The following examples illustrate the basic syntax of the language and use of the command-line interface.
In R and S, the [[Assignment (computer science)|assignment operator]] is an arrow made from two characters "<-". <source lang="rsplus"> > x <- c(1,2,3,4,5,6) # Create ordered collection (vector) > y <- x^2 # Square the elements of x > print(y) # print (vector) y [1] 1 4 9 16 25 36 > mean(y) # Calculate average (arithmetic mean) of (vector) y; result is scalar [1] 15.16667 > var(y) # Calculate sample variance [1] 178.9667 > lm_1 <- lm(y ~ x) # Fit a linear regression model "y = f(x)" or "y = B0 + (B1 * x)" # store the results as lm_1 > print(lm_1) # Print the model from the (linear model object) lm_1
Call: lm(formula = y ~ x)
Coefficients: (Intercept) x -9.333 7.000
> summary(lm_1) # Compute and print statistics for the fit of the (linear model object) lm_1
Call: lm(formula = y ~ x)
Residuals: 1 2 3 4 5 6 3.3333 -0.6667 -2.6667 -2.6667 -0.6667 3.3333
Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) -9.3333 2.8441 -3.282 0.030453 * x 7.0000 0.7303 9.585 0.000662 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 â***â 0.001 â**â 0.01 â*â 0.05 â.â 0.1 â â 1
Residual standard error: 3.055 on 4 degrees of freedom Multiple R-squared: 0.9583, Adjusted R-squared: 0.9478 F-statistic: 91.88 on 1 and 4 DF, p-value: 0.000662
> par(mfrow=c(2, 2)) # Request 2x2 plot layout > plot(lm_1) # Diagnostic plot of regression model </source>
[[File:Plots from lm example.svg|Diagnostic graphs produced by ''plot.lm()'' function. Features include mathematical notation in axis labels, as at lower left.]]
=== Example 2 ===
Short R code calculating [[w:Mandelbrot set|Mandelbrot set]] through the first 20 iterations of equation z = zÂ² + c plotted for different complex constants ''c''. This example demonstrates: * use of community developed external libraries (called packages), in this case caTools package * handling of [[complex numbers]] * multidimensional arrays of numbers used as basic data type, see variables C, Z and X <source lang="rsplus"> library(caTools) # external package providing write.gif function jet.colors <- colorRampPalette(c("#00007F", "blue", "#007FFF", "cyan", "#7FFF7F", "yellow", "#FF7F00", "red", "#7F0000")) m <- 1200 # define size C <- complex( real=rep(seq(-1.8,0.6, length.out=m), each=m ), imag=rep(seq(-1.2,1.2, length.out=m), m ) ) C <- matrix(C,m,m) # reshape as square matrix of complex numbers Z <- 0 # initialize Z to zero X <- array(0, c(m,m,20)) # initialize output 3D array for (k in 1:20) { # loop with 20 iterations Z <- Z^2+C # the central difference equation X[,,k] <- exp(-abs(Z)) # capture results } write.gif(X, "Mandelbrot.gif", col=jet.colors, delay=100) </source>
[[File:Mandelbrot Creation Animation.gif|400px|"Mandelbrot.gif" - Graphics created in R with 14 lines of code in Example 2]]
== Packages == The capabilities of R are extended through user-created ''packages'', which allow specialized statistical techniques, graphical devices, import/export capabilities, reporting tools, etc. These packages are developed primarily in R, and sometimes in [[Java (programming language)|Java]], [[C (programming language)|C]] and [[Fortran]]. A core set of packages are included with the installation of R, with more than 4300 ({{as of|2011|3|lc=on}}) available at the [http://cran.r-project.org/ Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN)], [[Bioconductor]], and other repositories. <ref name="bare_url">{{cite web | url = http://sites.google.com/site/r4statistics/popularity | author= Robert A. Muenchen | title = The Popularity of Data Analysis Software }}</ref>
The [http://cran.r-project.org/web/views/ "Task Views"] page (subject list) on the CRAN website lists the wide range of applications (Finance, Genetics, Machine Learning, Medical Imaging, Social Sciences and Spatial statistics) to which R has been applied and for which packages are available.
Other R package resources include Crantastic, a community site for rating and reviewing all CRAN packages, and also R-Forge, a central platform for the collaborative development of R packages, R-related software, and projects. It hosts many unpublished, beta packages, and development versions of CRAN packages.
The [[Bioconductor]] project provides R packages for the analysis of genomic data, such as [[Affymetrix]] and [[Complementary DNA|cDNA]] [[microarray]] object-oriented data handling and analysis tools, and has started to provide tools for analysis of data from next-generation [[high-throughput sequencing]] methods.
Reproducible research and automated report generation can be accomplished with packages such as Sweave and odfWeave that support execution of R code embedded within [[LaTeX]], [[OpenDocument|OpenDocument format]] and other markups<ref>http://cran.r-project.org/web/views/ReproducibleResearch.html</ref>.
== Milestones == <!-- List notable changes only; ignore service/bug-fig releases -->
The full list of changes is maintained in the [http://cran.r-project.org/src/base/NEWS NEWS] file. Some highlights are listed below.
* Version 0.16 â This is the last [[Software release life cycle#Alpha|alpha]] version developed primarily by Ihaka and Gentleman. Much of the basic functionality from the "White Book" (see [[S (programming language)#History|S history]]) was implemented. The mailing lists commenced on April 1, 1997. * Version 0.49 â April 23, 1997 â This is the oldest available [[Source code|source]] release, and compiles on a limited number of Unix-like platforms. CRAN is started on this date, with 3 mirrors that initially hosted 12 packages. Alpha versions of R for Microsoft Windows and [[Mac OS]] are made available shortly after this version. * Version 0.60 â December 5, 1997 â R becomes an official part of the [[GNU Project]]. The code is hosted and maintained on [[Concurrent Versions System|CVS]]. * Version 1.0.0 â February 29, 2000 â Considered by its developers stable enough for production use.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-announce/2000/000127.html|title=R-1.0.0 is released|author=Peter Dalgaard|accessdate=2009-06-06}}</ref> * Version 1.4.0 â S4 methods are introduced and the first version for [[Mac OS X]] is made available soon after. * Version 2.0.0 â October 4, 2004 â Introduced [[lazy loading]], which enables fast loading of data with minimal expense of system memory. * Version 2.1.0 â Support for [[UTF-8]] encoding, and the beginnings of [[internationalization and localization]] for different languages. * Version 2.11.0 â April 22, 2010 â Support for Windows 64 bit systems. * Version 2.13.0 â April 14, 2011 â Adding a new compiler function that allows speeding up functions by converting them to byte-code. * Version 2.14.0 - October 31, 2011 - Added mandatory namespaces for packages. Added a new parallel package.
== Interfaces ==
=== Graphical user interfaces === * RGUI â comes with the pre-compiled version of R * [[Java Gui for R]] â cross-platform stand-alone R terminal and editor based on [[Java (programming language)|Java]] (also known as JGR) * [http://www.deducer.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php?n=Main.DeducerManual Deducer] - GUI for menu driven data analysis (similar to [[SPSS]]/[[JMP]]/[[Minitab]]). * [[Rattle GUI]] â cross-platform GUI based on RGtk2 and specifically designed for [[data mining]] * [[R Commander]] â cross-platform menu-driven GUI based on [[tcl]]tk (several plug-ins to Rcmdr are also available) * [[RapidMiner]] <ref>[http://rapid-i.com/content/view/219/1/ R Extension Presented on RCOMM 2010]</ref> <ref>{{ cite web | url=http://www.kdnuggets.com/polls/2010/data-mining-analytics-tools.html | title= Data Mining / Analytic Tools Used Poll (May 2010) }}</ref> * [[RExcel]] â using R and Rcmdr from within [[Microsoft Excel]] * [http://www.red-r.org Red-R] â visual analysis interface that uses R for statistics * [[RKWard]] â extensible GUI and IDE for R * [http://www.ef-prime.com/products/ranalyticflow_en/ R AnalyticFlow] - analysis flowcharts with R (freeware) * [http://www.rstudio.org/ RStudio] - cross-platform open source IDE (which can also be run on a remote linux server) * [[Weka (machine learning)|Weka]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://CRAN.R-project.org/package=RWeka | publisher=Kurt Hornik, Achim Zeileis, Torsten Hothorn and Christian Buchta | title=RWeka: An R Interface to Weka. R package version 0.3-17 | accessdate=2009}}</ref> allows for the use of the data mining capabilities in Weka and statistical analysis in R.
=== Editors and IDEs ===
[[Text editor]]s and [[Integrated development environment]]s (IDEs) with some support for R include: [[Bluefish (text editor)|Bluefish]],<ref>''Customizable syntax highlighting based on Perl Compatible regular expressions, with subpattern support and default patterns for..R'', tenth bullet point, [http://bluefish.openoffice.nl/features.html Bluefish Features], Bluefish website, retrieved 9 July 2008.</ref> [[Crimson Editor]], RStudio,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rstudio.org | title=RStudio: new IDE for R | author=JJ Alaire and colleages | accessdate=2011-08-04 }} </ref> [[ConTEXT]], [[Eclipse (software)|Eclipse]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.walware.de/goto/statet | title=StatET: Eclipse based IDE for R | author=Stephan Wahlbrink | accessdate=2009-09-26 }} </ref> [[Emacs]] ([[Emacs Speaks Statistics]]), [[Vim (text editor)|Vim]], Tinn-R,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sourceforge.net/projects/tinn-r/ | title=Tinn-R Editor - GUI for R Language and Environment | publisher=Tinn-R Team | accessdate=2010-11-07}} </ref> [[Geany]], [[jEdit]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://community.jedit.org/?q=node/view/2339 | title=R syntax | author=Jose Claudio Faria | accessdate=2007-11-03 }} </ref> [[Kate (text editor)|Kate]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://kate-editor.org/downloads/syntax_highlighting | title=Syntax Highlighting | publisher=Kate Development Team | accessdate=2008-07-09 | archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080707062903/http://www.kate-editor.org/downloads/syntax_highlighting <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-07-07}} </ref> R Productivity Environment (part of Revolution R Enterprise),<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.revolutionanalytics.com/products/enterprise-productivity.php | title=R Productivity Environment | publisher=Revolution Analytics | accessdate=2011-09-03 }} </ref> [[TextMate]], [[gedit]], [[SciTE]], [[WinEdt]] (R Package RWinEdt), [[notepad++]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sourceforge.net/projects/npptor/ |title=NppToR: R in Notepad++ |publisher=sourceforge.net |accessdate=2010-07-11 |unused_data=Download NppToR: R in Notepad++ software for free at SourceForge.net }}</ref>.
=== Scripting languages === R functionality has been made accessible from several scripting languages such as [[Python (programming language)|Python]] (by the RPy<ref>[http://rpy.sourceforge.net RPy home page<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> interface package), [[Perl]] (by the Statistics::R<ref>[http://search.cpan.org/~gmpassos/Statistics-R-0.02/lib/Statistics/R.pm Statistics::R page on [[CPAN]]]</ref> module) and [[Ruby_(programming_language)|Ruby]] (with the rsruby<ref>[http://rubyforge.org/projects/rsruby/ RSRuby rubyforge project]</ref> [[rubygem]]). Scripting in R itself is possible via littler<ref>[http://dirk.eddelbuettel.com/code/littler.html littler web site]</ref> as well as via Rscript.
== Comparison with SAS, SPSS and Stata ==
The general consensus is that R compares well with other popular statistical packages, such as [[SAS_(software)|SAS]], [[SPSS]] and [[Stata]]<ref>[http://www.ats.ucla.edu/stat/technicalreports/Number1/R_relative_statpack.pdf Comparison of R to SAS, Stata and SPSS]</ref>. In January 2009, the ''[[New York Times]]'' ran an article about R gaining acceptance among data analysts and presenting a potential threat for the market share occupied by commercial statistical packages, such as SAS.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/07/technology/business-computing/07program.html | work=The New York Times | first=Ashlee | last=Vance | title=Data Analysts Captivated by R's Power | date=2009-01-07}}</ref>
== Commercial support for R == In 2007, [[Revolution Analytics]] was founded to provide commercial support for Revolution R, its distribution of R which also includes components developed by the company. Major additional components include: ''ParallelR''<ref>http://www.revolutionanalytics.com/news-events/news-room/2008/enhanced-statistical-analyses-with-parallelr.php</ref>, the ''R Productivity Environment'' IDE <ref>http://blog.revolutionanalytics.com/2009/11/rpe-the-r-productivity-environment-for-windows.html</ref>, ''RevoScaleR'' (for [[big data]] analysis) <ref>http://www.revolutionanalytics.com/news-events/news-room/2010/revolution-analytics-brings-big-data-analysis-to-R.php</ref>, ''RevoDeployR''<ref>http://blog.revolutionanalytics.com/2010/09/introducing-revodeployr-web-services-for-r.html</ref>, web services framework and the ability for reading and writing data in the SAS file format.<ref>[http://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/02/07/revolution_r_sas_challenge/ 'Red Hat for stats' goes toe-to-toe with SAS]</ref>
In Oct 2011, [[Oracle Corporation|Oracle]] announced the ''Big Data Appliance'', which integrates R, [[Apache Hadoop]], [[Oracle Enterprise Linux]], a [[NoSQL]] database with the [[Exadata]] hardware.<ref>[http://www.oracle.com/us/corporate/press/512001 Oracle Unveils the Oracle Big Data Appliance]</ref> <ref>[http://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/10/03/oracle_big_data_appliance/ Oracle rolls its own NoSQL and Hadoop]</ref>
Other major commercial software systems supporting connections to R include: [[Spotfire]]<ref>[http://spotfire.tibco.com/community/blogs/stn/archive/2010/03/08/spotfire-integration-with-s-and-r.aspx Spotfire Integration with S+ and R]</ref>, [[SPSS]]<ref>http://www.unt.edu/benchmarks/archives/2007/october07/rss.htm</ref>, [[STATISTICA]]<ref>http://www.statsoft.com/solutions/r-language-platform/</ref>, [[Symphony (software)|Platform Symphony]] <ref>[http://platformcomputing.blogspot.com/2011/03/r-integrated-with-symphony.html Râ integrated with Symphony]</ref>, [[SAS]]<ref>[http://support.sas.com/documentation/cdl/en/imlsstat/63545/HTML/default/viewer.htm#statr_toc.htm Calling Functions in the R Language (SAS/IML)]</ref>
